At 21:19 23/08/2004, you wrote:
>Ians Badco Wrote:
>
>::snip::
>A ---> B
>
>A ---> C ---> B
>
>is innovation n, but
>
>A ---> C ---> B
>
>mutating to
>
>A ---> C ---> B
>---> D --->
>
>(e.g. C and D both connecting A to B)
>
>is innovation m...
>::/snip::
>
>what if instead of innovation m, which NEAT cannot relate to n, m were 
>instead called n.1, which would imply that it is a copy of, but newer than 
>and different from, n?
>
>chad

Hi Chad,

Hmm, when I first read this, I thought "yeah, good idea" but then I 
wondered how NEAT would make use of the information.

Then I started wondering whether n was really "more like" the n in another 
individual than the n.1 in another individual.  That in turn lead me to 
think that it depended what other connections had been made to the node in 
question (this does only apply to node-introducing mutations?  e.g. we're 
not (yet) talking about inserting the same connection twice, are we?).

All of that lead me full circle to the idea that the equivalence of 
innovation number "defines" the equivalence of genes across individuals, 
rather than "measuring" it.  Once the genes are defined as equivalent then 
the process of crossover and selection will force them into playing the 
same role in the phenotype.

Individuals where two genes have the same innovation number but are not 
truly "equivalent" will be infertile with each other -- in biology, this is 
what defines a new species -- it cannot breed with the old species -- and 
the reverse also applies, once it no longer breeds with the old species, 
then its genes are free to drift away from the roles they played in the old 
species...

         Ian Badcoe
